aria-hidden="false">Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-103l8m3"><div class="css-1u5onbp epjyd6m1"><div class="css-165eim7 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/benjamin-mullin" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Benjamin Mullin" title="Benjamin Mullin" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/02/09/multimedia/author-benjamin-mullin/author-benjamin-mullin-thumbLarge.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-233int epjyd6m0"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/benjamin-mullin" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Benjamin Mullin</a></span></p></div></div></div><div data-testid="reading-time-module"><div class="css-3xqm5e"><time class="css-1g7pp1u e16638kd0" dateTime="2023-05-23T09:00:08-04:00">May 23, 2023</time></div></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">BuzzFeed parlayed the rising power of social media into a digital media business worth more than a billion dollars at its peak. But when technology giants behind social platforms moved away from publishing, BuzzFeed’s valuation cratered.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">To rebound, BuzzFeed is again turning to new technology: artificial intelligence.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The company has tried a variety of experiments since announcing plans to incorporate A.I. a few months ago, embracing the technology more than most publishers. On Tuesday, BuzzFeed introduced its most ambitious offering yet, a free chatbot called Botatouille (no relation to Pixar’s murine chef), which serves up recipe recommendations from <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/16/technology/tasty-internet-fads.html" title="">Tasty</a>, BuzzFeed’s food brand.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Botatouille is built using the technology that drives OpenAI’s popular ChatGPT program, customized with Tasty recipes and user data.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Rainy day? Botatouille recommends winter chili or lentil soup. Feeling lonely? Botatouille suggests chocolate chip cookies or a vegetable curry. Botatouille might also recommend shepherd’s pie, which it quipped was its mother’s recipe.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Shifting from a sort of crumbling wave of social to a growing wave of generative A.I., to me, is an exciting transition,” said Jonah Peretti, the company’s chief executive. “And I think there’s things we could definitely learn to make sure we capture more enduring value from a technological trend.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Though BuzzFeed is among the first media companies to experiment with artificial intelligence, many others are thinking about how to adapt to it. Executives at Bloomberg, Insider and The New York Times are all weighing the potential upside against risks to their existing businesses.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The possible pitfalls include a <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/30/business/media/publishers-chatbots-search-engines.html" title="">loss of traffic</a> from search engines, as A.I.-powered chatbots answer search queries. And some companies that use artificial intelligence for content creation have <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://futurism.com/cnet-ai-errors" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">already published</a> error-ridden articles.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mr. Peretti <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/20/business/buzzfeed-news-shut-down.html" title="">shut down</a> BuzzFeed News last month, but in the future, he said, BuzzFeed plans to experiment with A.I to enhance its news business, which is now organized under its HuffPost brand.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mr. Peretti said that might include using artificial intelligence to help create headlines for search engines or brainstorm ways to tell certain stories.</p><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-small css-1189og3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-zgakxe erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:580px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1ybnr6m ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Botatouille uses the technology that drives OpenAI’s popular ChatGPT program, customized with Tasty recipes and user data.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But he said he didn’t anticipate a future in which artificial intelligence would be used to replace HuffPost journalists.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Even if you were, like, an evil C.E.O. trying to replace all journalists with A.I., you would be very unsuccessful,” Mr. Peretti said. “It wouldn’t work on the business side.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">He said he was applying several lessons from BuzzFeed’s uneven relationship with social media to its experiments with artificial intelligence.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">When BuzzFeed used social media to expand its audience, it did not always make profitability a priority. The company grew quickly but has since fallen on harder times. It is now worth nearly $90 million — a small fraction of its peak of $1.7 billion in 2016. The shuttering of BuzzFeed News affected dozens of jobs.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The company is now focusing on building a sustainable business from the start, Mr. Peretti said. BuzzFeed plans to use artificial intelligence to sell subscriptions to its users by providing them personalized services and custom interactions on offerings like Botatouille, he said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“We are much more focused on monetization, and focused on it much earlier than we were back in those days,” Mr. Peretti said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">One big question for BuzzFeed: Will Botatouille work?</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Before attending a party on Sunday evening, I asked the chatbot to recommend a batch cocktail recipe to take.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Hey there! Sounds like you’re ready to party!” Botatouille responded in its usual chipper tone — and added an admonition to drink responsibly. “I recommend the ‘Boozy Bubbly Sherbet Punch.’ It’s a fun and fruity drink that’s perfect for a party.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Botatouille then shared the recipe, a coherent concoction of vodka, champagne and fruit juices from concentrate, topped with a scoop of rainbow sherbet.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Later, I asked Botatouille to suggest meals for a laid-off digital media worker. It initially struggled to give a response. “Oops. Something went wrong,” it said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Then it had an idea.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Hmm, it seems like you might be feeling a bit down. How about I recommend a meal that will lift your spirits?” Botatouille said. “For a laid-off digital media worker, I suggest trying the one-pan chicken and veggie meal prep 2 ways.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-ddxw8g"></div><div class="css-1jp38cr"><div class="css-cw8msf eqi4ubu0"><div class="css-kzd6pg"><p><span class=css-97bxx6><a class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/benjamin-mullin>Benjamin Mullin</a></span> is a media reporter for The Times, covering the major companies behind news and entertainment.<span class=css-kzd6pg> <a class="authorPageLinkClass overrideLinkStyles" href=https://www.nytimes.com/by/benjamin-mullin>More about Benjamin Mullin</a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="css-13ldwoe">A version of this article appears in print on <span class="css-1dmwf73"> </span>, Section <!-- -->B<!-- -->, Page <!-- -->4<!-- --> of the New York edition<!-- --> with the headline: <!-- -->BuzzFeed, in an Effort to Ride the A.I. intelligence.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":12,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"When BuzzFeed used social media to expand its audience, it did not always make profitability a priority. The company grew quickly but has since fallen on harder times. It is now worth nearly $90 million — a small fraction of its peak of $1.7 billion in 2016. The shuttering of BuzzFeed News affected dozens of jobs.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":13,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The company is now focusing on building a sustainable business from the start, Mr. Peretti said. BuzzFeed plans to use artificial intelligence to sell subscriptions to its users by providing them personalized services and custom interactions on offerings like Botatouille, he said.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":14,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“We are much more focused on monetization, and focused on it much earlier than we were back in those days,” Mr. Peretti said.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":15,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"One big question for BuzzFeed: Will Botatouille work?","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Before attending a party on Sunday evening, I asked the chatbot to recommend a batch cocktail recipe to take.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":16,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“Hey there! Sounds like you’re ready to party!” Botatouille responded in its usual chipper tone — and added an admonition to drink responsibly. “I recommend the ‘Boozy Bubbly Sherbet Punch.’ It’s a fun and fruity drink that’s perfect for a party.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":17,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Botatouille then shared the recipe, a coherent concoction of vodka, champagne and fruit juices from concentrate, topped with a scoop of rainbow sherbet.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":18,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Later, I asked Botatouille to suggest meals for a laid-off digital media worker. It initially struggled to give a response. “Oops. Something went wrong,” it said.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":19,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Then it had an idea.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“Hmm, it seems like you might be feeling a bit down. How about I recommend a meal that will lift your spirits?” Botatouille said. “For a laid-off digital media worker, I suggest trying the one-pan chicken and veggie meal prep 2 New Generation of Chatbots\",\"items\":[{\"subtitle\":\"A brave new world.\",\"text\":\"A new crop of chatbots powered by artificial intelligence has ignited a scramble to determine whether the technology \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F03\u002F08\u002Ftechnology\u002Fchatbots-disrupt-internet-industry.html\\\"\u003Ecould upend the economics of the internet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, turning today’s powerhouses into has-beens and creating the industry’s next giants. Here are the bots to know:\"},{\"subtitle\":\"ChatGPT.\",\"text\":\"ChatGPT, the artificial intelligence language model from a research lab, OpenAI, has been making headlines since November for its ability to respond to complex questions, write poetry, generate code, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F03\u002F16\u002Ftravel\u002Fchatgpt-artificial-intelligence-travel-vacation.html\\\"\u003Eplan vacations\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and translate languages. GPT-4, the latest version introduced in mid-March, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F03\u002F14\u002Ftechnology\u002Fopenai-new-gpt4.html\\\"\u003Ecan even respond to images\u003C\u002Fa\u003E (and ace the Uniform Bar Exam).\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Bing.\",\"text\":\"Two months after ChatGPT’s debut, Microsoft, OpenAI’s primary investor and partner, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F02\u002F07\u002Ftechnology\u002Fmicrosoft-ai-chatgpt-bing.html\\\"\u003Eadded a similar chatbot\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, capable of having open-ended text conversations on virtually any topic, to its Bing internet search engine. But it was the bot’s occasionally inaccurate, misleading and \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F02\u002F16\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbing-chatbot-microsoft-chatgpt.html\\\"\u003Eweird responses\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that drew much of the attention after its release.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Bard.\",\"text\":\"Google’s chatbot, called Bard, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F03\u002F21\u002Ftechnology\u002Fgoogle-bard-chatbot.html\\\"\u003Ewas released in March\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to a limited number of users in the United States and Britain. Originally conceived as a creative tool designed to draft emails and poems, it can generate ideas, write blog posts and \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F03\u002F21\u002Ftechnology\u002Fgoogle-bard-guide-test.html\\\"\u003Eanswer questions with facts or opinions\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Ernie.\",\"text\":\"The search giant Baidu unveiled China’s first major rival to ChatGPT in March. The debut of Ernie, short for Enhanced Representation through Knowledge Integration, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fworld\u002Fasia\u002Fchina-baidu-chatgpt-ernie.html\\\"\u003Eturned out to be a flop\u003C\u002Fa\u003E after a promised “live” demonstration of the bot was revealed to have been recorded.\"}]}},{\"version\":1,\"type\":\"guide\",\"data\":{\"title\":\"Explore Our Coverage of Artificial Intelligence\",\"leadIn\":\"\",\"sections\":[{\"section\":[{\"type\":\"bulletedList\",\"value\":[\"Amazon, Salesforce, Oracle and others \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F07\u002F05\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbusiness-ai-technology.html\\\"\u003Eare rolling out products that incorporate generative A.I.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to help workplaces become more efficient and productive.\",\"The tech industry loves its garage start-up stories. But the huge amounts of money and computing power needed to create new A.I. systems \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F07\u002F05\u002Fbusiness\u002Fartificial-intelligence-power-data-centers.html\\\"\u003Emay be making those inspirational tales a thing of the past\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\",\"Foreign investors betting on A.I. are pouring money into Samsung’s shares. But the company \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F07\u002F04\u002Ftechnology\u002Fsamsung-artificial-intelligence.html\\\"\u003Emight have a hard time keeping up with rivals\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\",\"Many Black artists are finding \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F07\u002F04\u002Farts\u002Fdesign\u002Fblack-artists-bias-ai.html\\\"\u003Eevidence of racial bias in A.I.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, both in the large data sets that teach machines how to generate images and in the programs that run the algorithms.\",\"The tech company Co-Star uses A.I. to generate horoscopes and astrological readings. With a machine able to answer open-ended questions, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F07\u002F04\u002Fstyle\u002Fastrology-co-star-ai.html\\\"\u003Eit is taking things even further\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\",\"A new generation of chatbots doesn’t have many of the guardrails put in place by companies like Google and OpenAI, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F07\u002F02\u002Ftechnology\u002Fai-chatbots-misinformation-free-speech.html\\\"\u003Epresenting new possibilities — and risks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\"]}]}]}}]}]}","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Fstoryline\u002Fc3f19d9c-d2cb-4619-8aea-ec3afa27be39","tone":"NO_TONE_SET","primaryAssets":[{"displayName":"Can A.I. oembed.title: BuzzFeed Tries to Ride the A.I. Wave. Who’s Hungry?
oembed.summary: Jonah Peretti, the company’s chief executive, has embraced artificial intelligence more than most publishers. His latest offering: Botatouille, an A.I.-powered kitchen assistant.
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2023%2F05%2F23%2Fbusiness%2Fmedia%2Fbuzzfeed-botatouille-chatbot-food.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="BuzzFeed Tries to Ride the A.I. Wave. Who’s Hungry?" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>

readabilityObject.title: BuzzFeed’s Botatouille Chatbot Puts A.I. Twist on Food Advice
readabilityObject.content:
Advertisement

SKIP ADVERTISEMENT

BuzzFeed Tries to Ride the A.I. Wave. Who’s Hungry?

Jonah Peretti, the company’s chief executive, has embraced artificial intelligence more than most publishers. His latest offering: Botatouille, an A.I.-powered kitchen assistant.

BuzzFeed parlayed the rising power of social media into a digital media business worth more than a billion dollars at its peak. But when technology giants behind social platforms moved away from publishing, BuzzFeed’s valuation cratered.

To rebound, BuzzFeed is again turning to new technology: artificial intelligence.

The company has tried a variety of experiments since announcing plans to incorporate A.I. a few months ago, embracing the technology more than most publishers. On Tuesday, BuzzFeed introduced its most ambitious offering yet, a free chatbot called Botatouille (no relation to Pixar’s murine chef), which serves up recipe recommendations from Tasty, BuzzFeed’s food brand.

Botatouille is built using the technology that drives OpenAI’s popular ChatGPT program, customized with Tasty recipes and user data.

Rainy day? Botatouille recommends winter chili or lentil soup. Feeling lonely? Botatouille suggests chocolate chip cookies or a vegetable curry. Botatouille might also recommend shepherd’s pie, which it quipped was its mother’s recipe.

“Shifting from a sort of crumbling wave of social to a growing wave of generative A.I., to me, is an exciting transition,” said Jonah Peretti, the company’s chief executive. “And I think there’s things we could definitely learn to make sure we capture more enduring value from a technological trend.”

Though BuzzFeed is among the first media companies to experiment with artificial intelligence, many others are thinking about how to adapt to it. Executives at Bloomberg, Insider and The New York Times are all weighing the potential upside against risks to their existing businesses.

The possible pitfalls include a loss of traffic from search engines, as A.I.-powered chatbots answer search queries. And some companies that use artificial intelligence for content creation have already published error-ridden articles.

Mr. Peretti shut down BuzzFeed News last month, but in the future, he said, BuzzFeed plans to experiment with A.I to enhance its news business, which is now organized under its HuffPost brand.

Mr. Peretti said that might include using artificial intelligence to help create headlines for search engines or brainstorm ways to tell certain stories.

But he said he didn’t anticipate a future in which artificial intelligence would be used to replace HuffPost journalists.

“Even if you were, like, an evil C.E.O. trying to replace all journalists with A.I., you would be very unsuccessful,” Mr. Peretti said. “It wouldn’t work on the business side.”

He said he was applying several lessons from BuzzFeed’s uneven relationship with social media to its experiments with artificial intelligence.

When BuzzFeed used social media to expand its audience, it did not always make profitability a priority. The company grew quickly but has since fallen on harder times. It is now worth nearly $90 million — a small fraction of its peak of $1.7 billion in 2016. The shuttering of BuzzFeed News affected dozens of jobs.

The company is now focusing on building a sustainable business from the start, Mr. Peretti said. BuzzFeed plans to use artificial intelligence to sell subscriptions to its users by providing them personalized services and custom interactions on offerings like Botatouille, he said.

“We are much more focused on monetization, and focused on it much earlier than we were back in those days,” Mr. Peretti said.

One big question for BuzzFeed: Will Botatouille work?

Before attending a party on Sunday evening, I asked the chatbot to recommend a batch cocktail recipe to take.

“Hey there! Sounds like you’re ready to party!” Botatouille responded in its usual chipper tone — and added an admonition to drink responsibly. “I recommend the ‘Boozy Bubbly Sherbet Punch.’ It’s a fun and fruity drink that’s perfect for a party.”

Botatouille then shared the recipe, a coherent concoction of vodka, champagne and fruit juices from concentrate, topped with a scoop of rainbow sherbet.

Later, I asked Botatouille to suggest meals for a laid-off digital media worker. It initially struggled to give a response. “Oops. Something went wrong,” it said.

Then it had an idea.

“Hmm, it seems like you might be feeling a bit down. How about I recommend a meal that will lift your spirits?” Botatouille said. “For a laid-off digital media worker, I suggest trying the one-pan chicken and veggie meal prep 2 ways.”

A version of this article appears in print on  , Section

B

, Page

4

of the New York edition

with the headline:

BuzzFeed, in an Effort to Ride the A.I. Wave, Introduces a Free Recipe Chatbot, Botatouille. Order Reprints | Today’s Paper | Subscribe
